THE NEWS LETTER
Vol. XIV. No. 27.
CHAMPIONSHIP LOST
Crippled Hopkins Lacrosse Team
.. No Match for the Sturdy Players from Swarthmore — Clary
Badly Injured.
By its defeat at the hands of the
Swarthmore team last Saturday, 16
to 3, the Hopkins lacrosse team lost
the championship of the Southern
Division of the Intercollegiate League
for the first time in five years. The
Winners outplayed their opponents at
all stages of the game, and they
Showed the dashing, aggressive spirit
that usually characterizes a championship team.
Hopkins was badly crippled. Captain Schmeisser, the mainstay of the
defense, could not play on account of
the injury he received in the Stevens
game. It was a sad blow to him, as
he had been looking to the game (luring the whole year. Gillet, the big
freshman, was prevented from playing by a death in his family. In
spite of these two instances of hard
luck the Hopkins team would have
made a far better showing but for the
fact that Clary had his collarbone
broken by a hard fall.
The rough Canadian tactics of the
husky Swarthmore players soon tired
out the lighter black and blue men.
The visitors ran about the field almost at will, beating down by sheer
strength the opposition of the Hopkins team.
Moore, the Swarthmore second attack, shot the first goal after a few
moments of play. Hall, the acting;
captain of the Pennsylvanians, followed with another tally. Eddie Hulburt temporarily raised the hopes of
the Hopkins contingent of rooters by
caging the ball from a very difficult
angle. Then Clary was forced t.)
stop on account of his injury. When
he left the field the close followers
Of the game saw that it was all up
With Hopkins' chances.
During the remainder of the half
Moore shot three more goals and
Perkins tallied twice. The half ended with the score 7 to I.
For a short time in the second half
the Hopkins players held down their
oPponents. But when the Swarthmore team got started it excelled even
Its fine work of the first session of
Play. As an incentive to roll up a
large score, each Swarthmore playev
Was promised a dollar for each goal
he shot. Perkins and Moore each
earned a 44\7,9 for himself in this way.
lburt and Gail each scored for
Ropkins in this half.
The whole Swarthmore team played well. Perkins and Moore were

the individual stars on the attack, but
they were finely supported at all
times by their teammates. By their
speed the maroon and white players
managed to get the "extra man" a
number of times, and as can be seen
from the score they usually made it.
count.
Stockett and Hulburt played well
for Hopkins. Raleigh, the acting captain, also did some fine work for the
local team, and Keith, at point, played a heady game. Gus Vogeler livened things up a bit at the end of
the second half. He gave his opponents some hard raps that delighted
the grandstand.

you wait, till next year.
Apropos the Hullabaloo controversy we print on another page a letter
from an alumnus which is well worth
reading. The writer has himself edited college annuals and writes from
experience. The News-Letter invites
additional expressions of opinion
from those who have any views on
the question.
The average cost of Yale's junior
"prom" festivities was $122.90 for
each man. One man spent $900, but
he entertained a house party. Omitting this, the average cost falls to
$105.25. Taking the entire junior
week into consideration, the sum averages $180.04.

VIRGINIA WINS
DUAL TRACK MEET
Hopkins Humbled by Old Rivals
by 65 Points to 3() — Lee and
Breyer Capture the Distance
Events.
(Special to The News-Letter.)
Charlottesville, Va., May 15.
Virginia won the annual traek meet
with Hopkins yesterday by 65 points
to 39. Hopkins lost the dashes, middle distance and field events, but captured both the mile and two-mile runs.
Horrax and Stanton divided individual honors, the former making 17
points for the black and blue.
All the events were run off in remarkably fast time, that for the hundred being 10 seconds flat. In this
Hunter breasted the tape a scant six
inches behind Stanton.
Stollenwerck pushed Stanton hard
in the 220, hut was beaten. Wiltshire, a Baltimore boy captured the
quarter and half-mile with ease. Fulton failing to pace in either event.

BASEBALL RECOGNIZED
Athletic Association Elects Officers, and Votes to Introduce
Game—Lively Discussion and
Great Interest.
On Monday of last week a largely
attended meeting was held by the
Athletic Association. The election of
officers resulted as follows:
President, J. M. Holmes.
Vice President, A. M. Chesney.
Corresponding Secretary,H. C.Burgan.
Alumni Delegate, Horace Burrows.
Graduate Delegate, C. S. Kelley.
Medical Delegate, Gilbert Horrax.
Senior Delegates, E. B. Clary and
J. R. Wolfe.
Junior Delegate, J. S. Fulton, Jr.
Sophomore Delegate, E. J. Pieper.
A motion was passed that the
corresponding secretary, on behalf of
the association, send a letter of sympathy to Dr. Renouf, whose son has
just died in China.
Owing to the absence of the regular cheer leader at the track meet
with the University of Virginia, C.
L. Packard was elected temporary
leader for the Swarthmore game.
During the counting of the ballots
for the officers, Mr. Hyland Stewart
moved that the Athletic Association
"recognize and support" a University
baseball team. This motion was the
signal for a spirited and prolonged
debate, during which the views of
both sides were expressed with vigor
an earnestness. A rising vote was
finally taken, and the motion was
carried by a considerable majority.
This action was the result of a
vigorous campaign by the supporters
of baseball, whose views had
on
many adherents during the past few
weeks. The decision to introduce
baseball makes this meeting historical in its importance to Hopkins athletics.
In speaking about the adoption of
baseball Dr. Magoffin, of the Historical Department, said:
"There is no reason why the University can not develop and support
a winning team. The number of students is increasing, and it ought not
to interfere with the lacrose and
track teams. Th success of the team
depends wholly upon the support given by the students."
Dr. Magoffin played on one of the
former Hopkins teams when he was
in the graduate department, and is at
present the "side-wheeler" of a team
recently formed by the students in
history and political science.

The protest of the sophomores
against the postponement of the Hullabaloo until their senior year adds
a disturbing element to a situation
already unique. Finding it impossible to publish their annual this year,
the juniors, by deciding to put it off,
have brought their plans into conflict with those of the sophomor,s,
and the latter refuse to yield. When
it is considered that the sophomores
have not only elected their board for
next year, but have even begun active work upon their book,the Arength
of their position becomes evient. At
the same time, it is essential that
there be no misunderstanding or dissension about so important an enterprise; and it is plainly the duty of
the student body to step in and arrange some agreement or compromise that shall be as fair as possible
to both parties. The failure of the
annual to appear this year is sufficiently unfortunate, without the additional annoyance of a dispute as to
who shall publish it next time.
The whole affair is an indication
of the inadvisability of too much class

The News-Letter hopes to publish
before the end of the session a series
of letters from the members of the
graduating class, in which they will
tell frankly just what benefits they
think they have derived from their
course at the University, what changes their experience suggests as desirable, and, if they care to do so,
what advice they wish to leave at
parting to their successors. These
communications should prove of interest to the readers of the paper,
and of more than passing value as
farewell messages front the students
we are about to lose.

May 9. Dr. William H. Welch presided, and introduced the speaker in
his graceful manner.
Professor Higginbottom is a missionary in the Naini Leper Asylum,
at Allahabad, India, and speaks from
experience. He quoted statistics
which show that there are now one
million lepers in Asia, four hundred
thousands of which are in India. Of
these, only nine thousand can be provided for in the asylums which now
exist. The Naini Asylum, where
Professor I ligginbotom teaches, has
two hundred and fifty inmates. The
leprosy is of two kinrs — anxsthetic
and tubercular. In the case of the
former, the sufferer loses all sensation in his limbs, and the fingers and
toes gradually drop off; while those
afflicted with tubercular leprosy are
covered with ulcers. Professor Higginbottom is now on furlough in the DOWNS'
United States, and is making a lecture tour during his vacation.

THE NEWS LETTER
Vol. XIV. No. 27.
CHAMPIONSHIP LOST
Crippled Hopkins Lacrosse Team
.. No Match for the Sturdy Players from Swarthmore — Clary
Badly Injured.
By its defeat at the hands of the
Swarthmore team last Saturday, 16
to 3, the Hopkins lacrosse team lost
the championship of the Southern
Division of the Intercollegiate League
for the first time in five years. The
Winners outplayed their opponents at
all stages of the game, and they
Showed the dashing, aggressive spirit
that usually characterizes a championship team.
Hopkins was badly crippled. Captain Schmeisser, the mainstay of the
defense, could not play on account of
the injury he received in the Stevens
game. It was a sad blow to him, as
he had been looking to the game (luring the whole year. Gillet, the big
freshman, was prevented from playing by a death in his family. In
spite of these two instances of hard
luck the Hopkins team would have
made a far better showing but for the
fact that Clary had his collarbone
broken by a hard fall.
The rough Canadian tactics of the
husky Swarthmore players soon tired
out the lighter black and blue men.
The visitors ran about the field almost at will, beating down by sheer
strength the opposition of the Hopkins team.
Moore, the Swarthmore second attack, shot the first goal after a few
moments of play. Hall, the acting;
captain of the Pennsylvanians, followed with another tally. Eddie Hulburt temporarily raised the hopes of
the Hopkins contingent of rooters by
caging the ball from a very difficult
angle. Then Clary was forced t.)
stop on account of his injury. When
he left the field the close followers
Of the game saw that it was all up
With Hopkins' chances.
During the remainder of the half
Moore shot three more goals and
Perkins tallied twice. The half ended with the score 7 to I.
For a short time in the second half
the Hopkins players held down their
oPponents. But when the Swarthmore team got started it excelled even
Its fine work of the first session of
Play. As an incentive to roll up a
large score, each Swarthmore playev
Was promised a dollar for each goal
he shot. Perkins and Moore each
earned a 44\7,9 for himself in this way.
lburt and Gail each scored for
Ropkins in this half.
The whole Swarthmore team played well. Perkins and Moore were

Baltimore, Md., May 16, 1910.
the individual stars on the attack, but
they were finely supported at all
times by their teammates. By their
speed the maroon and white players
managed to get the "extra man" a
number of times, and as can be seen
from the score they usually made it.
count.
Stockett and Hulburt played well
for Hopkins. Raleigh, the acting captain, also did some fine work for the
local team, and Keith, at point, played a heady game. Gus Vogeler livened things up a bit at the end of
the second half. He gave his opponents some hard raps that delighted
the grandstand.

defense; C. Collins, third deense ;

you wait, till next year.
Apropos the Hullabaloo controversy we print on another page a letter
from an alumnus which is well worth
reading. The writer has himself edited college annuals and writes from
experience. The News-Letter invites
additional expressions of opinion
from those who have any views on
the question.
The average cost of Yale's junior
"prom" festivities was $122.90 for
each man. One man spent $900, but
he entertained a house party. Omitting this, the average cost falls to
$105.25. Taking the entire junior
week into consideration, the sum averages $180.04.

VIRGINIA WINS
DUAL TRACK MEET
Hopkins Humbled by Old Rivals
by 65 Points to 3() — Lee and
Breyer Capture the Distance
Events.
(Special to The News-Letter.)
Charlottesville, Va., May 15.
Virginia won the annual traek meet
with Hopkins yesterday by 65 points
to 39. Hopkins lost the dashes, middle distance and field events, but captured both the mile and two-mile runs.
Horrax and Stanton divided individual honors, the former making 17
points for the black and blue.
All the events were run off in remarkably fast time, that for the hundred being 10 seconds flat. In this
Hunter breasted the tape a scant six
inches behind Stanton.
Stollenwerck pushed Stanton hard
in the 220, hut was beaten. Wiltshire, a Baltimore boy captured the
quarter and half-mile with ease. Fulton failing to pace in either event.

Great Interest.
On Monday of last week a largely
attended meeting was held by the
Athletic Association. The election of
officers resulted as follows:
President, J. M. Holmes.
Vice President, A. M. Chesney.
Corresponding Secretary,H. C.Burgan.
Alumni Delegate, Horace Burrows.
Graduate Delegate, C. S. Kelley.
Medical Delegate, Gilbert Horrax.
Senior Delegates, E. B. Clary and
J. R. Wolfe.
Junior Delegate, J. S. Fulton, Jr.
Sophomore Delegate, E. J. Pieper.
A motion was passed that the
corresponding secretary, on behalf of
the association, send a letter of sympathy to Dr. Renouf, whose son has
just died in China.
Owing to the absence of the regular cheer leader at the track meet
with the University of Virginia, C.
L. Packard was elected temporary
leader for the Swarthmore game.
During the counting of the ballots
for the officers, Mr. Hyland Stewart
moved that the Athletic Association
"recognize and support" a University
baseball team. This motion was the
signal for a spirited and prolonged
debate, during which the views of
both sides were expressed with vigor
an earnestness. A rising vote was
finally taken, and the motion was
carried by a considerable majority.
This action was the result of a
vigorous campaign by the supporters
of baseball, whose views had
on
many adherents during the past few
weeks. The decision to introduce
baseball makes this meeting historical in its importance to Hopkins athletics.
In speaking about the adoption of
baseball Dr. Magoffin, of the Historical Department, said:
"There is no reason why the University can not develop and support
a winning team. The number of students is increasing, and it ought not
to interfere with the lacrose and
track teams. Th success of the team
depends wholly upon the support given by the students."
Dr. Magoffin played on one of the
former Hopkins teams when he was
in the graduate department, and is at
present the "side-wheeler" of a team
recently formed by the students in
history and political science.

The protest of the sophomores
against the postponement of the Hullabaloo until their senior year adds
a disturbing element to a situation
already unique. Finding it impossible to publish their annual this year,
the juniors, by deciding to put it off,
have brought their plans into conflict with those of the sophomor,s,
and the latter refuse to yield. When
it is considered that the sophomores
have not only elected their board for
next year, but have even begun active work upon their book,the Arength
of their position becomes evient. At
the same time, it is essential that
there be no misunderstanding or dissension about so important an enterprise; and it is plainly the duty of
the student body to step in and arrange some agreement or compromise that shall be as fair as possible
to both parties. The failure of the
annual to appear this year is sufficiently unfortunate, without the additional annoyance of a dispute as to
who shall publish it next time.
The whole affair is an indication
of the inadvisability of too much class

The News-Letter hopes to publish
before the end of the session a series
of letters from the members of the
graduating class, in which they will
tell frankly just what benefits they
think they have derived from their
course at the University, what changes their experience suggests as desirable, and, if they care to do so,
what advice they wish to leave at
parting to their successors. These
communications should prove of interest to the readers of the paper,
and of more than passing value as
farewell messages front the students
we are about to lose.

May 9. Dr. William H. Welch presided, and introduced the speaker in
his graceful manner.
Professor Higginbottom is a missionary in the Naini Leper Asylum,
at Allahabad, India, and speaks from
experience. He quoted statistics
which show that there are now one
million lepers in Asia, four hundred
thousands of which are in India. Of
these, only nine thousand can be provided for in the asylums which now
exist. The Naini Asylum, where
Professor I ligginbotom teaches, has
two hundred and fifty inmates. The
leprosy is of two kinrs — anxsthetic
and tubercular. In the case of the
former, the sufferer loses all sensation in his limbs, and the fingers and
toes gradually drop off; while those
afflicted with tubercular leprosy are
covered with ulcers. Professor Higginbottom is now on furlough in the DOWNS'
United States, and is making a lecture tour during his vacation.
